description: Poland is closing schools and universities for two weeks from thursday the 12th of March to the 15th of March. Speaking at a joint conference following a special meeting on coronavirus, the ministers said that pre-schools and schools would stop teaching on Thursday, but limited care would still be provided this week to the youngest children.

type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down

description:
Poland issued an ordinance that restricts movement of individuals on New Years Eve from 7pm 31.12.2020 to 6am 01.01.2021. All movement outside is prohibited except if:

b) carrying out necessary needs related to the current affairs of everyday life.

description:
From Sunday, 15 March, Poland will close its borders to foreigners. All Polish citizens who are presently abroad can return to their homeland. International passenger air flights and international rail travel will be suspended for 10 days, with possibility of extension.

description: Poland announced on the 23rd of March that it would let some prisoners serve their sentences at home under electronic supervision to curb the spread of the coronavirus in prisons. description:
Poland introduced a closure of public services; including bars, restaurants (excluding take-out), shops and spas on the 14th of March. 

Update #1: Measures will be extended until April 19.

Update #2: The polish government announced that from March 31st onwards new public services are included in the list: Hotels, cosmetic and tattoo saloons, massage parlours and hairdressers must close. Stores selling household items such as paints and tiles which have recently seen increased custom must also shut at weekends. Shops that remain open must serve only the elderly from 1000 am till midday.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down

description:
Poland introduced a closure of public services; including bars, restaurants (excluding take-out), shops and spas on the 14th of March.

description: On the 14th of March a closure of non-essential businesses was announced, which included bars, restaurants, spas and most shops. On the 31st of March other businesses were included: Hotels, cosmetic and tattoo saloons, massage parlours and hairdressers must close. On the 20th of April: shops were allowed to open under restrictions. The other businesses remain closed for an undetermined period (including personal grooming, bars, spas etc).

description:
On the 14th of March a closure of non-essential businesses was announced, which included bars, restaurants, spas and most shops. On the 31st of March other businesses were included: Hotels, cosmetic and tattoo saloons, massage parlours and hairdressers must close. On the 20th of April: shops were allowed to open under restrictions. The other businesses remain closed for an undetermined period (including personal grooming, bars, spas etc).
On the 4th of May, shopping centres and hotels were allowed to open under restrictions. Other businesses remain closed for an undetermined period. UPDATE: From the 4th of May, shopping centres and hotels are allowed to reopen. Bars/restaurants/fitness clubs/recreational areas/cinemas remain closed.

description: On the 14th of March a closure of non essential businesses was announced by the Polish government, this was made stricter to include more businesses on the 31st of March. The Polish government has since in steps allowed certain business to open up. on 6th June it will open the remaining businesses: cinemas, theatres, operas, ballet, swimming pools, gyms, fitness clubs, play rooms, and theme parks. Fairs, exhibitions, and congresses will also be allowed. Saunas, solaria, tatoo and massage salons will also be opened (from 30th of May) UPDATE: On the 14th of March a closure of non essential businesses was announced by the Polish government, this was made stricter to include more businesses on the 31st of March. description: Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki decided on Tuesday March 10 to cancel all mass events in the country, among other preventive measures undertaken to contain the virus. A mass gathering is defined as at least 1000 people at locations other than buildings, or at least 500 people inside a building.
On March 10th 2020 the Polish government announced that mass events are cancelled with no clear definition of mass provided
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Polish government is issuing a complete ban on gatherings of more than 2 persons from March 24th onwards. There are two exceptions: families (i.e. 2 parents walking with their 2 children is allowed) and places of worship (maximum of 5 people).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On March 24th the Polish government stated that starting March 25th 2020 that all gatherings and events beyond families and those living together are banned
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The Polish government is issuing a complete ban on gatherings of more than 2 persons from March 24th onwards. There are two exceptions: families (i.e. 2 parents walking with their 2 children is allowed) and places of worship (maximum of 1 person per 15 sq meters - before April 20th this was a max of 5 people in total). UPDATE: Originally, only 5 people were allowed to convene in places of worship. On the 20th of April this has been changed to 1 person per 15 sq meters. Other restrictions remain in place.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On May 27th the Polish government issued that groups of up to 150 people allowed to organize with 2m distance between participants begining on May 30th 2020
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From October 10th onwards, in Poland, "capacity at cultural events in closed spaces will be capped at 25 percent of the available number of seats, while in open spaces it will be limited to 100 people, with only one customer per five square metres." For 'red zones', "cultural events will be banned"
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Poland imposes rules for public transport: travellers must keep enough distance so they must leave a row of seats between them. This means that only half the seats can be used.
On May 13th the Polish government mandated that a density of one person per 4 square meters of space, at least 2 meters between tables
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
